Description.val:
FY 2020 funding totals include $0.0M for Base and $41.013M for Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO); of which $40.048M is realigned as part of the OCO for Base Requirements.  FY 2020 OCO for Base Requirements is OCO funding for base budget requirements in support of the National Defense Strategy.  The Budget requests these funds in OCO to comply with the base budget defense caps included in the Budget Control Act of 2011.

Beginning in FY18 this budget represents a consolidation of ammunition line items by functional capability.

This budget includes demolition items, hand held grenades, vehicle launched grenades, pyrotechnic devices, land mines, and non-lethal items. 

Demolition items provide high explosives for the purpose of destroying or altering man-made or natural objects or obstacles.  Demolition munitions charges include block charges, shaped charges, flexible-linear charges, explosive sheet, cable, canine explosive scent items, chain cutters, and military dynamite. They are used for general demolition, cutting, breaching, cratering, and destruction of abandoned equipment/ammunition.  

Also included are all hand held/vehicle launched grenades, pyrotechnics devices, and land mines used by ground forces of the Marine Corps.  This includes colored smoke grenades, obscuration smoke grenades, various pyrotechnics used in training to simulate battlefield effects, and the claymore mines.  

Additionally, this family also has non-lethal munition variants such as; 12 gauge, 40mm grenades, diversionary grenades, and 81mm non-lethal mortars. These munitions are intended to incapacitate, warn or drive off targeted personnel and/or materiel; while minimizing permanent injury to personnel, and damage to property in the target area or environment.

The funds prior to FY18 are contained in line items 1030, 1468, 1500 and 1628.

Justification.val:
FY 2020 OCO for baseline funding is required for procurement of Hand Grenades (DODIC G881), linear charges (DODIC M913), Arrester Cable Release Mechanism (ACRM) (DODIC MLAC), Anti-Personnel Obstacle Breaching Systems (APOBS) (DODIC MN79), Military Dog Scent Kit (MDSK) items, M6 Electric Blasting Caps (DODIC M130), Demolition Flex Linear Charges (DODICs MM46 and MM47), and Lightweight Disposable Disruptors (LIDD) (DODIC DWDN). All procured items will support required annual and pre-deployment training. 

FY 2020 funding is also required for Engineering Support In Production (ESIP). ESIP costs support engineering functions on produced units which includes configuration management, lot acceptance testing, and support for items currently in production.  Additionally, this funding addresses any changes to the design, assuring that the ammunition is of the highest quality, and deals with any manufacturing concerns during these processes.

The increase from FY 2019 to FY 2020 reflects an increase of the munitions requirement for APOBS (MN79), Charge, Demo Linear H3 (M913), Grenade, Hand Fragmentation M67 (G881), Cap, Blasting Electric (M130), and Charge, Demolition FLSC (MM46) and (MM47).  In the case of GG20 and MDSK, increase in funding is due to shelf life-related attrition of stocks to support current inventory.

OCO: 
The FY 2020 Direct War OCO funding request of $0.965M is required to reset APOBS (DODIC MN79) munitions expended in support of Operation Inherent Resolve (OIR).  Funding will procure additional APOBS (DODIC MN79) to support required training, this includes annual training requirements as well as any pre-deployment training.

Name.val: A4 SERIES LINEAR DEMOLITION CHARGE M58

Name.@footnote: M913: Budget Year (2020) unit costs have been adjusted to reflect the latest estimates obtained from the OSD summer pricing review, this cost is used for all services procuring the same configuration.

The increase in unit cost is due to an overall lower quantity being procured on the Army's contract in FY 2020 as compared to FY 2019.  The Marine Corps is procuring a larger quantity in FY20.  However, when combined with the Army's smaller quantity in FY 2020 the overall quantity drops significantly.  As a result, increasing the unit cost.
